awd_titl_txt: P2C2: Paleoclimatology of Cuba based on Stalagmite Oxygen Isotope Records--Hydrological Sensitivity and Causes of Variability in the Caribbean Region
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to reconstruct precipitation changes in the Caribbean and Golf of Mexico regions during the Holocene. The precipitation reconstruction will be based on stable isotopic composition of Oxygen and trace elements (Magnesium/Calcium and Strontium/Calcium ratios) measured from stalagmites collected in Western Cuba. In addition, climate model simulations over the last millennium will be used to investigate the large-scale climate dynamics associated with extreme events revealed by the stalagmite oxygen isotope records. These new data together with the data-model synthesis have the potential to improve the understanding of the hydroclimate variability drivers in the Caribbean and Golf of Mexico regions, including the role of tropical cyclones.  

The potential Broader Impacts include: 1) a continuous and highly resolved paleorainfall record from western Cuba spanning the last 16.000 years; 2) a greater understanding of the hydroclimate variability in the Caribbean and Golf of Mexico regions and the underlying mechanism of extreme events; and 3) estimates of hydrological cycle sensitivity to external (e.g. orbital forcing) and internal (e.g. El Nino Southern Oscillation) processes of the climate system. This project will support graduate students to receive analytical and theoretical training in paleoclimate research from tropical speleothem records.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

General public summary

Title: Paleoclimatology of Cuba based on stalagmite oxygen isotope records: hydrological sensitivity and causes of variability in the Caribbean region

Summary of Outcomes:

Our research project on exploring climate variability and human adaptation in the Caribbean region has yielded significant outcomes and advancements over the course of the award period. Through the analysis of stalagmite records we have achieved important milestones in our understanding of past climate dynamics, drivers of climate variability, and the impacts on human societies. This summary provides a concise overview of the key outcomes and achievements of our project.

  1. Precipitation Variability from interannual to millennial timescales: By analyzing high-resolution hydroclimate records from stalagmite specimens, including the specimens CL and C2, we have gained valuable insights into the long-term history of precipitation variability in the Caribbean region. Our findings have illuminated patterns and rapid changes in climate regimes over thousands of years, enhancing our understanding of past hydroclimate conditions.
  2. Identification of Climate Drivers: Through the analysis of stable isotopes and other relevant data, we have made significant progress in identifying the drivers of climate variability in the Caribbean region. Our research has advanced the understanding of the interplay between internal and external climate processes, providing insights into the mechanisms influencing hydroclimate changes in the Caribbean over different timescales, from interannual to millennial timescales and, thus far, during two climate states; the Late Holocene and during the transition from a glacial to an interglacial period (e.g. the last deglaciation). This project may also potentially extend the paleoclimate record of the Caribbean region to two even more ancient time intervals, that from 26 to 64 thousand years before present (the last glacial period) and from 194-264 thousand years before present (the antepenultimate glacial to interglacial period) .
  3. Climate Modeling and Projections: Our project offers to contribute to the validation and improvement of climate models specific to the Caribbean region. By comparing empirical data from stalagmite records with model results, we can enhance the accuracy and reliability of regional climate projections. This advancement supports evidence-based decision-making and climate adaptation strategies in the face of future climate change.
  4. Interdisciplinary Collaboration: Collaboration across disciplines has been a key component of our project's success. By integrating findings from social sciences and anthropology, we can enrich our understanding of the relationship between climate change and human societies. This interdisciplinary approach can yield valuable insights into the impacts of climate variability on ancient civilizations and cultures, particularly on the Paleo-Indians from the Mesolithic in western Cuba and the Maya in the Yucatan Peninsula, contributing to cultural history and adaptation studies.
  5. Training and Development of Human Resources: Our project has provided training and research opportunities to three graduate students, including an underrepresented minority female student. Through mentorship and skill development in paleoclimatology, data analysis, and scientific communication, this project has nurtured the next generation of climate scientists, contributing to the growth and expertise of the field.
  6. Dissemination of Knowledge: We are disseminating our research findings through scientific manuscripts, conference presentations, and educational exhibits to contribute to public understanding of climate change, paleoclimatology, and the importance of understanding past climate dynamics. This dissemination can empower individuals to make informed decisions and take action in addressing climate-related challenges.

These outcomes have broader impacts on society, contributing to evidence-based decision-making, resilience-building, and the promotion of scientific literacy.
